description: Identifier name used for BioSample. Max length is 50 characters.
Descriptive title for sample.
Optional description for sample.

required_column: At least one field required. Group: At least one required: Group "Organism
description: At least one required: Group "Organism". microbial or eukaryotic strain name

required_column: At least one field required. Group: At least one required: Group "Organism
description: At least one required: Group "Organism". identification or description of the specific individual from which this sample was obtained

required_column: At least one field required. Group: At least one required: Group "Organism
description: At least one required: Group "Organism". cultivar name - cultivated variety of plant

required_column: At least one field required. Group: At least one required: Group "Organism
description: At least one required: Group "Organism". a population within a given species displaying genetically based, phenotypic traits that reflect adaptation to a local habitat, e.g., Columbia

Additional (i.e. secondary, tertiary, etc.) recovery methods deployed for increase of hydrocarbon recovery from resource and start date for each one of them, e.g., water injection {timestamp}, dump flood {timestamp}, gas injection {timestamp}, wag immiscible injection {timestamp}, polymer addition {timestamp}, surfactant addition {timestamp}
API gravity is a measure of how heavy or light a petroleum liquid is compared to water (source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/API_gravity), e.g. 31.1 API
Name of the basin, e.g. Campos

Add terms that identify the major environment type(s) where your sample was collected. Recommend subclasses of biome [ENVO:00000428]. Multiple terms can be separated by one or more pipes e.g.:  mangrove biome [ENVO:01000181]|estuarine biome [ENVO:01000020]

Add terms that identify environmental entities having causal influences upon the entity at time of sampling, multiple terms can be separated by pipes, e.g.:  shoreline [ENVO:00000486]|intertidal zone [ENVO:00000316]

Add terms that identify the material displaced by the entity at time of sampling. Recommend subclasses of environmental material [ENVO:00010483]. Multiple terms can be separated by pipes e.g.: estuarine water [ENVO:01000301]|estuarine mud [ENVO:00002160]

Geographical origin of the sample; use the appropriate name from this list http://www.insdc.org/documents/country-qualifier-vocabulary. Use a colon to separate the country or ocean from more detailed information about the location, eg "Canada: Vancouver" or "Germany: halfway down Zugspitze, Alps"
Main hydrocarbon type produced from resource, e.g., oil, gas-condensate, gas, bitumen, coalbed methane

Main hydrocarbon resource type. The term Hydrocarbon Resource is defined as a natural environmental feature containing large amounts of hydrocarbons at high concentrations potentially suitable for commercial exploitation, e.g., oil reservoir, gas reservoir, oil sand, coalbed, shale, tight oil reservoir, tight gas reservoir
PMID or url for isolation and growth condition specifications
Proportion of the produced fluids derived from injected water at the time of sampling, e.g., 87%
The geographical coordinates of the location where the sample was collected. Specify as degrees latitude and longitude in format "d[d.dddd] N|S d[dd.dddd] W|E", eg, 38.98 N 77.11 W
concentration of nitrate
Sampling point on the asset where sample was collected, e.g., well, test well, drilling rig, wellhead, separator, storage tank

The type of material from which the sample was obtained. For the Hydrocarbon package, samples include types like core, rock trimmings, drill cuttings, piping section, coupon, pigging debris, solid deposit, produced fluid, produced water, injected water, swabs, etc. For the Food Package, samples are usually categorized as food, body products or tissues, or environmental material. This field accepts terms listed under environmental specimen (http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/GENEPIO_0001246)
concentration of sulfate
concentration of sulfide
temperature of the sample at time of sampling
Current amount of water (%) in a produced fluid stream; or the average of the combined streams
Information that doesn't fit anywhere else
alkalinity, the ability of a solution to neutralize acids to the equivalence point of carbonate or bicarbonate
Method used for alkalinity measurement
concentration of ammonium

Saturate, Aromatic, Resin and Asphaltene (SARA) is an analysis method that divides crude oil components according to their polarizability and polarity. There are three main methods to obtain SARA results. The most popular one is known as the Iatroscan TLC-FID and is referred to as IP-143 (source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saturate,_aromatic,_resin_and_asphaltene)

Saturate, Aromatic, Resin and Asphaltene (SARA) is an analysis method that divides crude oil components according to their polarizability and polarity. There are three main methods to obtain SARA results. The most popular one is known as the Iatroscan TLC-FID and is referred to as IP-143 (source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saturate,_aromatic,_resin_and_asphaltene)
Concentration of benzene in the sample
List of biocides (commercial name of product and supplier) and date of administration
Method of biocide administration (dose, frequency, duration, time elapsed between last biociding and sampling), e.g., 150 mg/l; weekly; 4 hr; 3 days
Free-living or from host (define relationship)
concentration of calcium
Method of chemical administration, dose, frequency, duration, time elapsed between administration and sampling, e.g., 50 mg/l; twice a week; 1 hr; 0 days

List of chemical compounds administered upstream the sampling location where sampling occurred, e.g., glycols, H2S scavenger, corrosion and scale inhibitors, demulsifiers, and other production chemicals. The commercial name of the product and name of the supplier should be provided. The date of administration should also be included
concentration of chloride
Process used to collect the sample, e.g., bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL)
density of sample

Main depositional environment (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Depositional_environment), e.g., continental - alluvial, continental - aeolian, continental - fluvial, continental - lacustrine, transitional - deltaic, transitional - tidal, transitional - lagoonal, transitional - beach, transitional - lake, marine - shallow, marine - deep, marine - reef, other - evaporite, other - glacial, other - volcanic
concentration of dissolved carbon dioxide
dissolved inorganic carbon concentration
concentration of dissolved inorganic phosphorus
Concentration of dissolved iron in the sample
concentration of dissolved organic carbon
Concentration of dissolved oxygen in the oil field produced fluids as it contributes to oxgen-corrosion and microbial activity, e.g. Mic
Estimated size of genome
Concentration of ethylbenzene in the sample
Plasmids that have significance phenotypic consequence
Name of the hydrocarbon field, e.g., Albacora
Original formation water salinity (prior to secondary recovery e.g. Waterflooding) expressed as TDS

Geological age of hydrocarbon resource (additional info: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Period_(geology)), e.g., archean, cambrian, carboniferous, cenozoic, cretaceous, devonian, jurassic, mesozoic, neogene, ordovician, paleogene, paleozoic, permian, precambrian, proterozoic, silurian, triassic
Original pressure of the hydrocarbon resource
Original temperature of the hydrocarbon resource
The natural (as opposed to laboratory) host to the organism from which the sample was obtained. Use the full taxonomic name, eg, "Homo sapiens".
Name of relevant disease, e.g. Salmonella gastroenteritis. Controlled vocabulary, http://bioportal.bioontology.org/ontologies/1009 or http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/mesh
NCBI taxonomy ID of the host, e.g. 9606
Describes the physical, environmental and/or local geographical source of the biological sample from which the sample was derived.
Injection water breakthrough date per well following a secondary and/or tertiary recovery

Hydrocarbon resource main lithology (Additional information: http://petrowiki.org/Lithology_and_rock_type_determination), e.g., basement, chalk, chert, coal, conglomerate, diatomite, dolomite, limestone, sandstone, shale, siltstone, volcanic
concentration of magnesium
any other measurement performed or parameter collected, that is not listed here

The substance or equipment used as a negative control in an investigation, e.g., distilled water, phosphate buffer, empty collection device, empty collection tube, DNA-free PCR mix, sterile swab, sterile syringe
concentration of nitrite
Number of replicons in nuclear genome

A unique identifier of the omics-enabled observatory (or comparable time series) your data derives from. This identifier should be provided by the OMICON ontology; if you require a new identifier for your time series, contact the ontology's developers. Information is available here: https://github.com/GLOMICON/omicon. This field is only applicable to records which derive from an omics time-series or observatory.

If qpcr was used for the cell count, the target gene name, the primer sequence and the cycling conditions should also be provided, e.g., 16S rrna; FWD:ACGTAGCTATGACGT REV:GTGCTAGTCGAGTAC; initial denaturation:90C_5min; denaturation:90C_2min; annealing:52C_30 sec; elongation:72C_30 sec; 90 C for 1 min; final elongation:72C_5min; 30 cycles
total count of any organism per gram or volume of sample,should include name of organism followed by count; can include multiple organism counts
oxygenation status of sample
To what is the entity pathogenic
pH measurement
Ploidy level of genome (eg., haploid, diploid)
The substance, mixture, product, or apparatus used to verify that a process which is part of an investigation delivers a true positive
concentration of potassium

Temperature at which a liquid becomes semi solid and loses its flow characteristics. In crude oil a high pour point is generally associated with a high paraffin content, typically found in crude deriving from a larger proportion of plant material (source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/pour_point)
pressure to which the sample is subject, in atmospheres
Oil and/or gas production rates per well, e.g., 524 m3/day
Date of field's first production
phage: lytic/lysogenic/temperate/obligately lytic; plasmid: incompatibility group; eukaryote: asexual/sexual
Primary publication or genome report
Name of the reservoir, e.g., Carapebus

Saturate, Aromatic, Resin and Asphaltene (SARA) is an analysis method that divides crude oil components according to their polarizability and polarity. There are three main methods to obtain SARA results. The most popular one is known as the Iatroscan TLC-FID and is referred to as IP-143 (source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saturate,_aromatic,_resin_and_asphaltene)
salinity measurement
Method or device employed for collecting sample

Metal corrosion rate is the speed of metal deterioration due to environmental conditions. As environmental conditions change corrosion rates change accordingly. Therefore, long term corrosion rates are generally more informative than short term rates and for that reason they are preferred during reporting. In the case of suspected MIC, corrosion rate measurements at the time of sampling might provide insights into the involvement of certain microbial community members in MIC as well as potential microbial interplays
Processing applied to the sample during or after isolation
Preservative added to the sample, e.g. Rnalater, alcohol, formaldehyde. Where appropriate include volume added, e.g. Rnalater; 2 ml
Amount or size of sample (volume, mass or area) that was collected
Name of sample sub-type, e.g., oil phase, water phase, biofilm, not applicable
Sample transport duration (in days or hrs) and temperature the sample was exposed to (e.g., 5.5 days; 20C)
volume (mL) or weight (g) of sample processed for DNA extraction
Name of the well where sample was taken, e.g., BXA1123

Saturate, Aromatic, Resin and Asphaltene (SARA) is an analysis method that divides crude oil components according to their polarizability and polarity. There are three main methods to obtain SARA results. The most popular one is known as the Iatroscan TLC-FID and is referred to as IP-143 (source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saturate,_aromatic,_resin_and_asphaltene)
sodium concentration

unique identifier assigned to a material sample used for extracting nucleic acids, and subsequent sequencing. The identifier can refer either to the original material collected or to any derived sub-samples.
Information about the genetic distinctness of the lineage (eg., biovar, serovar)
Original sulfate concentration in the hydrocarbon resource
concentration of substances including a wide variety of material, such as silt, decaying plant and animal matter, etc,; can include multiple substances

Total Acid Number (TAN) is a measurement of acidity that is determined by the amount of potassium hydroxide in milligrams that is needed to neutralize the acids in one gram of oil. It is an important quality measurement of crude oil. (source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Total_acid_number)
Concentration of toluene in the sample
Concentration of total iron in the sample
total nitrogen content of the sample
total phosphorus concentration, calculated by: total phosphorus = total dissolved phosphorus + particulate phosphorus. Can also be measured without filtering, reported as phosphorus
Concentration of total sulfur in the sample
Feeding position in food chain (eg., chemolithotroph)
True vertical depth subsea (TVDSS) of the hydrocarbon resource where the original pressure was measured, e.g., 1578 m
True vertical depth subsea (TVDSS) of the hydrocarbon resource where the original temperature was measured, e.g., 1345 m
Concentration of Volatile Fatty Acids in the sample
Original volatile fatty acid concentration in the hydrocarbon resource
A measure of oil's resistance to gradual deformation by shear stress or tensile stress (e.g., 3.5 cp; 100C)
Water production rates per well, e.g., 987 m3/day

A unique identifier of a well or wellbore. This is part of the Global Framework for Well Identification initiative which is compiled by the Professional Petroleum Data Management Association (PPDM) in an effort to improve well identification systems. (Supporting information: https://ppdm.org/ and http://dl.ppdm.org/dl/690)
Concentration of xylene in the sample

Optional internal field for how the BioSample submission should be named when viewed from the NCBI submission portal. If not provided, when performing submissions <--submission_name> with the suffix "-BS" will be used instead.
Optional internal field explaining the purpose of the submission for when interacting and resolving submission issues with NCBI.
